name: Neo-noir
description: Blade Runner's retro-futurist setting lends it a timeless quality, while also connecting it to the past and the future.

key_work.title: Special effects in Blade Runner (Hades landscape)
key_work.brief_description: Blade Runner (1982) opens on a hellish Los Angeles skyline with no horizon in sight, but it’s far less expansive than it seems. Known as the ‘Hades landscape’, it was made from models, matte paintings and used practical effects to look like a living city.

constellations_primary.name: Neo-noir
constellations_primary.description: Blade Runner's retro-futurist setting lends it a timeless quality, while also connecting it to the past and the future.

start.title: Special effects in Blade Runner (Hades landscape)
start.brief_description: Blade Runner (1982) opens on a hellish Los Angeles skyline with no horizon in sight, but it’s far less expansive than it seems. Known as the ‘Hades landscape’, it was made from models, matte paintings and used practical effects to look like a living city.

constellations_primary.name: Neo-noir

end.title: Blade Runner
end.brief_description: Blade Runner is an adventure game with an emphasis on detective work rather than on puzzles. There are very few “real” puzzles in the game, and the gameplay mainly consists of questioning suspects, gathering evidence, etc. There are also some action sequences, and throughout the game the protagonist has the ability to use his gun. The player’s decisions can (and will) influence the outcome of the story, bringing the game to one of the six possible endings.

constellations_other.name: Neo-noir
constellations_other.description: Blade Runner's retro-futurist setting lends it a timeless quality, while also connecting it to the past and the future.

links.description: Blade Runner had two videogame tie-ins. The first, in the mid-80s, was a run-and-gun arcade game with little to do with the film. The second is a point-and-click detective game, taking place in the same world and unpacking many of the film’s themes and plot points.

constellations_other.name: Neo-noir
constellations_other.description: Blade Runner's retro-futurist setting lends it a timeless quality, while also connecting it to the past and the future.

links.description: The neo-noir cityscape of Blade Runner was a key influence on Pokémon Detective Pikachu. To achieve this, cinematographer John Mathieson, who had previously worked with Ridley Scott, shot on 35mm film, and used as many practical effects as possible.

end.title: Home Alone
end.brief_description: Eight-year-old Kevin McCallister makes the most of the situation after his family unwittingly leaves him behind when they go on Christmas vacation. But when a pair of bungling burglars set their sights on Kevin’s house, the plucky kid stands ready to defend his territory. By planting booby traps galore, adorably mischievous Kevin stands his ground as his frantic mother attempts to race home before Christmas Day.

constellations_other.name: Colour and illusion
constellations_other.description: Exploring the science of colour, light, reflection and movement.

constellations_other.name: Neo-noir
constellations_other.description: Blade Runner's retro-futurist setting lends it a timeless quality, while also connecting it to the past and the future.

constellations_other.name: Houses that move us
constellations_other.description: Our homes are important to us. When they’re good, they’re our havens. If that home changes, or things go wrong, it can affect us very deeply. This constellation looks at the different ways directors and game devs have positioned the home onscreen - from sanctuary, to hostile enemy.

recommendations.quote: This legendary Christmas film penned by John Hughes is one of the most quotable films in history. But it's not just a screwball kid's comedy about Kevin overcoming his fears, it's equally about maternal devotion and Catherine O'Hara's Kate McAllister quest to reunite with her son.

links.description: In Detective Pikachu, Justice Smith searches his father’s empty apartment, where a television is playing a clip from Angels with Filthy Souls, a fictional gangster film created for Home Alone.

end.title: Angels with Dirty Faces
end.creator_credit: Hal B. Wallis, Jack L. Warner, Samuel Bischoff and Ben Hecht
end.brief_description: Early on two pickpocketing best friends were separated. One was sent to reform school and the other to be a priest. In this love-loyalty melodrama we see different transitions and how people change.

constellations_other.name: Neo-noir
constellations_other.description: Blade Runner's retro-futurist setting lends it a timeless quality, while also connecting it to the past and the future.

links.description: The title of Home Alone‘s film-within-a-film Angels with Filthy Souls (and its equally fictional sequel, Angels with Even Filthier Souls) both reference the 1938 James Cagney gangster film Angels with Dirty Faces.

start.title: Angels with Dirty Faces

constellations_primary.name: Neo-noir

links.description: To achieve the noir look of futuristic Los Angeles, Ridley Scott filmed on the New York Street set of Warner Bros backlot. A staple of hundreds of films, the New York Street set instantly recalls many noir and gangster films, including Angels with Dirty Faces.

links.description: Detective Pikachu is a point-and-click detective game, a genre that reached its peak in the 90s, with titles like Grim Fandango and Blade Runner.

start.title: Blade Runner
start.brief_description: Blade Runner is an adventure game with an emphasis on detective work rather than on puzzles. There are very few “real” puzzles in the game, and the gameplay mainly consists of questioning suspects, gathering evidence, etc. There are also some action sequences, and throughout the game the protagonist has the ability to use his gun. The player’s decisions can (and will) influence the outcome of the story, bringing the game to one of the six possible endings.

end.title: The Beehive
end.credit_line:
Zanny Begg

Digital video, stereo sound, variable duration

Artbank + ACMI Commission, ACMI Collection
end.material_description: Single channel digital video and software, colour and audio
end.brief_description: The Beehive explores the unsolved murder of Sydney anti-development campaigner Juanita Nielsen. The inaugural Artbank + ACMI Commission, the video installation examines themes of gentrification, corruption, sex-work, feminism and non-conformist lifestyles.

constellations_other.name: Neo-noir
constellations_other.description: Blade Runner's retro-futurist setting lends it a timeless quality, while also connecting it to the past and the future.

constellations_other.name: Women and crime
constellations_other.description: The allure and fascination of dangerous women and women in danger.

links.description: The 1997 Blade Runner game was one of the first to include a procedurally generated ending, where the outcome of the case is different each time you play it. Similarly, Zany Begg’s artwork The Beehive uses an algorithm to determine the order of scenes.
